Award.AwardTitle: Investigating dynamic friction using earthquake ruptures produced in the laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research that will advances fundamental understanding of dynamic friction laws by performing mini-earthquakes in the laboratory. Dynamic friction plays a pivotal role in how earthquake ruptures propagate along pre-existing faults in the Earth's crust, such as the San Andreas Fault in California, and release waves that cause destructive shaking. Yet, the fundamental structure and evolution of dynamic friction is still one of the main uncertainties in earthquake science. The proposed study will enhance our understanding of dynamic friction and hence of earthquake source physics. By improving friction formulations for earthquake-producing faults, this study strives to produce a key ingredient for dynamic rupture simulations and physics-based assessment of seismic hazard.

The study will investigate dynamic friction using laboratory experiments, featuring dynamic ruptures spontaneously propagating along a frictional interface. The researchers will employ a digital image correlation technique in combination with high-speed photography to characterize in real time the full-field evolution of displacements, velocities, and stresses, and of friction along rupturing interfaces. The addition of rock gouge to the interface of the samples in some experiments will further increase the relevance of the setup to earthquake problems. Furthermore, plans to study friction evolution at locations where a fault meets a free surface and where fault-normal stresses vary rapidly and significantly, will allow tests for recent ideas of shear resistance not being directly proportional to rapid variations in normal stress but rather evolving to such proportionality with slip. The work will also explore the effect of fluids in faulting by conducting experiments with fluid injection and studying the regime in which the injection triggers dynamic events. The obtained friction data will help to evaluate and improve the existing dynamic friction formulations by introducing the appropriate new physics in to existing formalisms and by even suggesting new and improved dynamic frictional laws. The inferred friction formulations will be verified by forward simulations of our experimental setup.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamic friction, with its dependence on rapidly evolving rupture parameters such as slip and its rate, is a key aspect of earthquake physics and a crucial input to simulations of both single dynamic ruptures and long-term earthquake behavior. Assumptions about dynamic friction, e.g. about the degree of its rate dependence, affect conclusions about a wide range of earthquake-related topics, including energy partitioning, rupture modes, stress levels on faults, and patterns of seismic/aseismic slip.  One of the goals of our study is to clarify the slip dependence vs. slip rate dependence of dynamic friction in a simpler but still physically realistic system of our laboratory earthquake setup.

In this project we have explored the evolution of dynamic friction under a wide range of slip and slip rate histories, using an experimental setup developed to study earthquakes in the laboratory. The experiments also make use of our recently developed full-field dynamic imaging technique, which combines digital image correlation (DIC) with ultrahigh-speed photography and produces displacement, particle velocity, strain, and stress maps at a level of detail that was only possible to achieve with numerical simulations, until recently. This wealth of data is used to characterize the behavior of dynamic ruptures and to extract information about friction evolution with slip and slip rate. Our experimental measurements of friction using analog materials are consistent with rate-and-state friction supplemented with flash heating, but not with the widely used linear slip-weakening laws. We have also enriched our setup to incorporate rock gouge into a specimen made with an analog material . This configuration exploits the low shear modulus and associated small nucleation length scales of analog materials, necessary to host a well-developed dynamic rupture within a small specimen size, while at the same time includes rock gouge on the interface controlling friction evolution with a rheology relevant for real faults. Our findings indicate that gouge too has a behavior consistent with rate-and-state friction supplemented with flash heating. 

During the course of this study, we have investigated the evolution of shear resistance with rapid changes of normal stress. Friction formulations typically assume shear resistance to be proportional to normal stress. However, when normal stress changes rapidly enough, frictional shear resistance no longer obeys proportionality to the normal stress but rather evolves with slip gradually. Our experimental measurements clearly demonstrate the delay between normal stress changes and the corresponding changes in frictional resistance, with important implications for the dynamics of thrust earthquakes near the free surface.

In addition to study friction evolution we have also investigated the relation between fluids and faulting. For this purpose we have further developed a fluid injection setup that allows to inject fluid along a simulated fault under a wide range of pressure time histories. Our measurements indicate that rapid pore pressure increase results in unstable slip at lower pressure levels compared to slow injection. However, slow pore pressure increase produces more pronounced stress drops. 

The outcomes of this project contribute to our fundamental understanding of dynamic friction and hence earthquake physics. They have improved friction formulations for earthquake-producing faults, a key ingredient in dynamic rupture simulations and physics-based assessment of seismic hazard. Several students and a postdoctoral fellow have had valuable research experience participating in the interdisciplinary activities of this project.  The results have been disseminated through publications in leading professional journals and at professional meetings. We have used the results of our study to graphically illustrate earthquakes and to teach the associated science questions to high-school and middle-school students and their teachers, since the conducted experiments and simulations provide a unique insight into earthquake physics.
